awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Last Glacial Termination in Interior Asia
awd_abstract_narration:
The climate event that ended the last ice age - dubbed the "last glacial termination" - involved the greatest natural global warming of the recent geologic past. This was also the last time in which atmospheric CO2 rose by a substantial amount prior to the industrial period.  The last glacial termination therefore represents a spectacular natural experiment played out by the Earth system that can be studied in order to decipher the underlying dynamics of the climate system and its sensitivity to forcing factors, such as atmospheric CO2.  This project aims to determine when, and how rapidly, glaciers receded and the climate warmed at the end of the last ice age in the heart of Asia - Earth's largest and most populous continent. This research will help identify factors that produced this last great global warming, and to clarify the role of atmospheric CO2 in ice-age climate cycles. This work will provide immersive, field-based, and cooperative educational experiences for the next generation of scientists.  The project will bring together a research team that includes underrepresented high-school students and STEM teachers from the South Side of Chicago, graduate and undergraduate students from the U.S.A., Mongolia, and China, and graduate students of science journalism. The overarching goal is to establish and nurture international and cross-cultural educational and scientific partnerships that are built to last well beyond the duration of this project.

Identifying the causes of the last glacial termination is a major objective of the earth and climate sciences, and requires detailed chronologies of sensitive paleoclimate proxies that monitored the last glacial-to-interglacial transition across the planet. The purpose of this CAREER research is to develop such chronologies from the center of Asia for the reduction of mountain glacier extent from the peak of the last ice age to today's conditions. Glacier chronologies will be based on precise and accurate 10Be surface-exposure dating of glacial landforms in the mid-latitude Altai range of Mongolia and in the monsoonal eastern Himalaya of China. Glaciological modeling will convert these glacier reconstructions into records of glacier-inferred atmospheric temperature, which will in turn be compared with signatures of incoming solar radiation, greenhouse gases, as well as other proposed drivers, to discriminate among possible causes of the last termination. This project will be carried out following an integrated research and education plan that implements a cooperative, field-based learning strategy in which students at different levels learn by teaching each other.  The collaborative, cross-cultural, multi-national, and multi-generational team will share knowledge and experiences in the field and throughout the scientific process.  This team will consist of (1) graduate and undergraduate students from the University of Maine, (2) students and researchers from Mongolian and Chinese institutions, (3) students and science teachers from the Gary Comer College Preparatory school ? a public charter school devoted to improving the lives of underserved minority students from the South Side of Chicago, and (4) embedded science journalism graduate students from the Medill School of Journalism who will produce stories for publication and broadcast, thus documenting scientific outcomes for the public.

por.por_cntn:
The great global warming that terminated the last ice age featured a reorganization of the ocean-atmosphere system and involved the greatest planetary warming of the recent geological past. This warming event represents a natural experiment that can be studied to gain insight into the fundamental physics of the climate system and its propensity for change under different forcing agents. The goal of this NSF CAREER project was to examine the pattern of ice loss during the last glacial termination to develop insights into the climatic drivers. The effort focused on the mountain chains of interior Asia, where exceptionally well-preserved glacial landforms, called moraines, chart the recession of climatically sensitive ice masses during the last deglaciation. A key question is whether glacier systems in the northern middle latitudes, such as those in Asia, receded at the same time as those in the Southern Hemisphere. Whether the pattern of deglaciation was synchronous (or not) between the hemispheres bears on the climatic mechanisms that drove deglaciation. We sought to investigate this problem by developing detailed chronologies for the last glacial termination using "surface-exposure dating", in which the concentrations of cosmogenic nuclides, such as 10Be, in rock surfaces can help determine how much time has passed since a land surface became free of glacier ice and exposed to the sky. Diverse, multi-cultural, collaborative teams consisting of graduate students, undergraduates, high school students and teachers, and students of science journalism embarked on three major field campaigns to the remote glacial environments of the Altai Mountains of western Mongolia, and the high ranges of the southeastern Tibetan Plateau, China. The teams developed high-resolution maps and digital terrain models glacial landforms using uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs) and collected rock samples for 10Be surface-exposure dating. Altogether, results indicate that the glacier systems chosen for study had achieved maximal extents synchronously with ice-age glacier maxima around the world. In Mongolia, this glacial maximum condition ended shortly after ~19,000 years ago, at which time extensive ice recession began. Ice recession to near-interglacial limits had taken place by ~16,000 years ago. Glacier systems of the southeastern Tibetan Plateau exhibited similar timing of ice recession. The glacier chronologies reconstructed as part of this CAREER award exhibit striking similarity to glacier chronologies at the opposite end of an Asia-Zealandia transect in the Southern Alps of New Zealand. Rapid glacier recession at either end of this transect occurred despite opposing signals of orbitally modulated insolation intensity during that interval. These results instead suggest that coeval glacier recession was due to a change to Earth's energy budget between ~18,000 and ~16,000 years ago. We posit that a rapid poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies (dubbed the "Zealandia Switch") led to an increase in area of the Indo-Pacific Warm Pool, the "heat engine of the planet", which in turn drove an increase in poleward atmospheric heat transport capable of driving simultaneous glacier melt between interior Asia and the Southern Hemisphere.
